title: Efflorescence: The Comprehensive Guide
summary: Everything you need to know about those white powdery patches on brick walls. Causes, prevention, and permanent cures.

children.text: Efflorescence is a crystalline deposit of salts that can form on the surface of brick, concrete, or other masonry products. It appears as a white, powdery substance and is a common concern for homeowners.
Three conditions must exist simultaneously for efflorescence to occur:
Water-soluble salts must be present in the masonry.
Moisture must be present to dissolve these salts.
A path must exist for the salt solution to migrate to the surface and evaporate.

content.text: The simplest way to prevent efflorescence is to control moisture. Ensure proper drainage and use water-repellent sealers.

title: Thermal Conductivity: Clay vs. Concrete
summary: A scientific comparison of thermal lag and insulation properties. Why clay homes stay 5Â°C cooler in Indian summers.

children.text: In the sweltering heat of the Indian sub-continent, the choice of building material defines the comfort of the occupants. Terracotta (burnt clay) has been the material of choice for millennia, not just for tradition, but for physics.
Thermal lag is the time it takes for heat to pass through a material. Concrete transfers heat rapidly. Clay, being porous, traps air and slows down this transfer.

content.text: A 9-inch clay brick wall has a thermal lag of approx 8 hours. This means peak afternoon heat only reaches the interior by late evening, when windows can be opened.

title: Wirecut vs. Handmade: A Buyer's Guide
summary: Confused between sharp edges and rustic textures? We explain the manufacturing differences and aesthetic outcomes of both styles.

children.text: When choosing exposed bricks, the manufacturing process determines the final look. The two primary methods are Wirecut (Extruded) and Handmade (Moulded).
These are machine-extruded and cut with a wire tension. They offer sharp edges, uniform sizes, and higher compressive strength. Best for modern, clean lines.
Thrown into a mould by hand. Each brick is unique, with creases and soft edges. They are perfect for heritage restoration or giving a 'lived-in' feel to new homes.
